item.title: On Train Journeys
item.description: A perfectly known future is already the past When you’re on a long train journey through India, you’ll see a lot of “small stations” where most of the trains dont stop. Even if they do, that’s usually not for the sake of someone to get off/board the train. The trains stop there only when they’re ahead of time, or if they have some issue with the route ahead. When I look at these stations, I feel a weird urge to get off into that small station, especially during night time.

item.title: Why Pigeons don't fly off to Hawaii
item.description: I live in a place where we have a lot of pigeons, most of them live in the abandoned/unused flats in some of the buildings. Nobody likes them, but still you’ll see little bowls of grains and water on a large number of the windows. We don’t like them, but we feed them anyways. I personally keep a bowl of water too. When they see that the bowl’s empty, they just stare into it and then fly away after a while.

item.title: Purulia
item.description: Not far from the city of Kolkata lies a small district where you’ll still find people living lives long forgotten by the city dwellers. It’s a place which still prefers to watch the world zoom ahead through one of it’s national highways. This post is a small and rather forgettable (unless you’re the author himself) memoir of some of my overly specific memories in Purulia. Of course like any other road-trip I’ve taken with my brother and my dad, this one also started with us stopping by in the morning for chaa/chai (bengali/hindi for “tea”) on a small shop near Shaktigarh.

item.title: School
item.description: One of my older posts describes a little bit about my experiences in school. But at this point I feel like it deserves a place of it’s own. Which is here. The school in which I spent a large part of my childhood was Amrita Vidyalayam Kolkata. It was the first time that I had the chance to ride on a school bus. The problem with the bus was that it’s pickup point was a little far from home.

item.title: AI is only as powerful as the language it understands
item.description: You cannot evolve faster than your language because the language defines the culture of meaning ~ Terrence McKenna There are theories out there which state that the world out there is completely different from the one we perceive. Much like a “dream world” which correlates with the real world as mentioned by Joshua Bach in one of his appearances in the Lex Fridman Podcast. We can look at our perception as a compression algorithm which gives us just enough information about the world to do the things we do.
